doc.field: Merkel: Elucidation of scandal possible without Kohl's cooperation

In the opinion of CDU Secretary General Merkel, her party will succeed in shedding light on the party donations scandal even without the help of former Chancellor Kohl. Ms. Merkel has accused Kohl of compounding the party's plight through his refusal to reveal the donors. The Chancellor had put his word of honor above the law, Ms. Merkel added. But democracy can only work if laws are adhered to, otherwise "we are progressing toward a state of anarchy," Ms. Merkel said. With respect to the accounts in Lichtenstein and alleged bribes in connection with the sale of the chemical plant Leuna to Elf-Aquitaine, Ms. Merkel commented that she had no evidence of criminal acts by the former government.

The family of Wolfgang Huellen has raised doubts as to whether dealth of the financial expert of the CDU parliamentary group was indeed suicide. The family's lawyer, Mr. Wackers, told "Bild am Sonntag" he would request an autopsy. The lawyer rejected suspicions that Mr. Huellen might have embezzled money of the parliamentary group. There have been no unusual transactions on Mr. Huellen's account. The 49-year-old had been found hanged on Thursday in his Berlin apartment. The prosecution is investigating embezzlement charges against him.
The Greens Southwest call Kohl traitor

The Greens of Baden-Wuerttemberg have called former Chancellor Kohl a traitor. At their party convention in Mannheim, a communique was issued which includes a passage charging Kohl with repeatedly breaking his oath of office and thereby committing an unprecedented assault on the political culture of Germany and a dimension of treason. The head of the Green's delegation to the Bundesrat, Mr. Schlauch, accused Kohl of mocking democracy. Kohl had been violating the constitution day in, day out, Mr. Schlauch said.
Hessian CDU closed behind Minister President Koch

Hesse's Minister President Koch can rely on his party's support. At a meeting in Hofheim in the Taunus range, the state party delegates were solidly behind Koch. Only yesterday it became known that several million marks are missing from the CDU's bank accounts abroad. Kohl rejected the Opposition's demand to dissolve Parliament and to hold new elections. Koch: "The Parliament of Hesse must decide if it is capable to act. The Parliament has the right to return its mandate to the voter only if it is no longer capable of fulfilling its duties. And I emphasize for the government: The government is fully functional, there is no reason to suspend its work. And we want to face the voter at a moment when we have had a chance to implement what we had promised before the elections. By our work can then be judged if we have been capable."
Daimler-Chrysler to found its own bank

The Daimler-Chrysler corporation wants to found its own bank and expand its insurance business. The chairman of Daimler-Chrysler subsidiary Debis, Mr. Mangold, told "Welt am Sonntag" that experiences in the USA to that effect have been positive. It was shown that besides auto insurance, there was a demand for home and life insurance as well.
Leads to booty from Reemtsma kidnapping

The millions of marks from the Reemtsma kidnapping that have since disappeared may be hidden on the cemetery of the Belgian city of Raren. An anonymous telephone call to that effect was made to a Belgian newspaper. The paper reported that a man with local accent had said the booty was hidden in specific graves. The authorities are taking the case very seriously, it was said. Attempts to track down the caller have been so far unsuccessful.

The long-distance runner Dieter Baumann has been suspended from competitions as a result of doping suspicions. The German Track and Field Association has filed for a two-year suspension for the Olympia champion. The executive board strongly suspects that Baumann has taken illegal medications. The athlete assured his innocence saying that unknown persons had injected the medications into his toothpaste.
Kiefer reaches third round in Australia Open
Nicolas Kiefer has won against Karem Alani from Morocco in three sets and has thereby reached third round in the Australian Open in Melbourne.
Schmitt wins World Cup Ski Jumping in Sapporo
Two-time world champion Martin Schmitt has won the world cup ski jumping in Sapporo in Japan by a large margin before Ahonen from Finland.
